Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A fixed nonconducting sphere X has a charge <math alttext="positive 2 Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and a radius <math alttext="uppercase R sub X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Another nonconducting sphere, Y, has mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, radius <math alttext="uppercase R sub Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and charge <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Sphere Y starts from rest at some initial location and is acted on by a constant external force <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> so that it moves toward sphere X before coming to rest at a position where the distance between the centers of the spheres is <math alttext="lowercase r sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume gravitational forces are negligible.

(a) Describe the acceleration of sphere Y as sphere Y is brought closer to sphere X.

(b) The charge on sphere Y is increased to <math alttext="positive 2 Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and it again starts from rest at the same initial location and is acted upon by an identical constant external force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The closest distance between the centers of the spheres is <math alttext="lowercase r sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="lowercase r sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="lowercase r sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your answer.

Two conducting spheres, A and B, are both charged with charge <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The spheres are far apart compared to their size. The radius of sphere B is twice the radius of sphere A. Sphere A is connected by a wire to a resistor <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is connected to an open switch S. Sphere B is connected by a wire to the opposite side of switch S, as shown in the figure above.

(c) Is the electric field at the surface of sphere A greater than, less than, or equal to the electric field at the surface of sphere B? Justify your answer.

At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> switch S is closed. Immediately after the switch is closed, the current in the resistor is <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(d) Immediately after the switch is closed, is there a current in switch S? If there is a current in switch S, indicate the direction of this current. Justify your answer.

(e) Which of the graphs above shows the current in the resistor <math alttext="I sub uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time t? Justify your answer.

Switch S is reopened and the spheres are grounded. Spheres A and B are again both charged to <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. An identical resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is added in series with the original resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure below.

(f) Switch S is again closed. Immediately after the switch is closed, the current in the resistor is <math alttext="I sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="I sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer in terms of relevant physics principles.

(g) Switch S is opened and the spheres are grounded. Sphere A is again charged to <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is then placed inside a conductive spherical shell such that the sphere and shell do not touch. The shell is given a net charge of <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. In this configuration, what is the total charge located on the inner surface of the shell? Justify your answer.
